posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
Hi everybody,

Our programming team uses school-provided windows laptops, vscode, and github.  Each student has their own github account with a fork of the team repo, and we use pull requests and code reviews to manage contributions.  This workflow works fine when each student can be sure to always use the same laptop, which contains their github credentials (in a somewhat-hidden place), but if the laptops ever get switched around for any reason, it‚Äôs a nightmare.

If your team does something similar with student accounts, do you have a solution for credential management other than ‚Äúmake sure to always use the same laptop‚Äù?

Thanks!

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Does each student have their own Windows login, or is it a common account?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: there is one windows account on each machine called something like ‚ÄúEngineering Student.‚Äù  these are locally-managed machines, not windows-domain-managed machines, so we could create more local accounts, i guess, we‚Äôd just have to manage them all ourselves.  that would keep the students from unwittingly checking in under the wrong name, i guess.

posts.name: gcschmit
posts.cooked:
Instead of using forks of the repository, we create branches for each ‚Äúfeature‚Äù that is being developed. We still use pull requests to pull those branches into the main branch. It is easy to switch between branches using VS Code and the current branch is always displayed in the lower-right corner. So, the same laptop can be used to develop software for any feature and students have developed the habit to check which branch is active.

We still have the issue where students may remain logged into GitHub on a laptop that another student is now using. While this can make it harder to figure out who made which commit, with the one-feature-per-branch model, we usually know who is working on which branch.

(I‚Äôm assuming the nightmare that you reference is related to students working in a different fork without realizing it. If there‚Äôs a different nightmare, none of this may be helpful!)

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: thanks, it is indeed the nightmare of discovering, after you have checked in to somebody else‚Äôs fork, that you can‚Äôt push.  it was a bigger problem when we had more of a shortage of ‚Äúgood‚Äù machines, the students would race to grab the fast ones.

posts.name: Thomas Baeyens
posts.cooked: we do the same as 3061 with branches rather than pull requests, but to make things easier for credentials, we have all the laptops logged into a single github account that has access to all the repos. In order to keep the actual commit author information correct (so that we can see who is working on what), we use the Git User Profile extension on vscode. It makes switching between git info easy.

link_counts.title: Git Config User Profiles - Visual Studio Marketplace

posts.name: Nilesh Agarwalla
posts.cooked:
We have a team of about 45 students, about 10 of whom are on the software team. We recently purchased 6 laptops for the software team and have also wondered the best way manage them.

Here are a few of our requirements:

Each SW team member needs their own GitHub account (to ensure we can follow a basic code review process)

Each SW team member needs their own login to the laptop (to avoid using the wrong GitHub account, and to also allow students to have their own separate coding workspaces)

Other students (e.g. business team) may need to borrow a laptop temporarily

After mulling over options, we decided to implement a simple (and cheap) Samba based Active Directory Domain Controller (AD DC) to manage user access to the laptops.  I currently have it running on an old Raspberry Pi 3 and plan to deploy it in the next week or so.  Each laptop would join the domain and the users can be managed centrally via a web GUI.

One caveat is that the data would not be sync‚Äôd between laptops, but we plan to use that to encourage pushing changes frequently to a GitHub branch.

Anyway, I‚Äôm in the process of writing up all the steps and will share on this thread when it is complete.  I just wanted to share the solution that we came up with.  We shall see how it works in reality this season.

posts.name: Vlad B
posts.cooked:
BrownGenius:

One caveat is that the data would not be sync‚Äôd between laptops, but we plan to use that to encourage pushing changes frequently to a GitHub branch.

I‚Äôd agree with this, especially as using tools that also deploy a commit has can be very helpful in tracking down issues.

Samba AD seems a bit overkill, but I‚Äôm sure it‚Äô ll prove useful. You do need Windows Pro for it to work (for domains on Windows), which has always been my deterrent.

posts.name: Nilesh Agarwalla
posts.cooked:
vladb:

Samba AD seems a bit overkill, but I‚Äôm sure it‚Äô ll prove useful. You do need Windows Pro for it to work (for domains on Windows), which has always been my deterrent.

Initially, I also thought Samba AD was overkill.  The mentors were actually were just joking about it, but the more I thought about it, I realized it was much easier than the alternate of adding the same logins for each laptop and/or sharing logins. For teams with just 1-2 laptops and/or student that have personal laptops, AD is definitely overkill, but hopefully it does prove useful for us this year.

Also, regarding Windows Professional, there are many legitimate license key resellers (e.g. https://wholsalekeys.com/ ).  A few days ago, I bought a 5-pack Windows 10 Pro license for $15 and upgraded our older Windows 10 Home laptops by just typing in the key and rebooting.

posts.name: Eric Liefeld
posts.cooked:
We use GitHub and give every student an account as you do.

We purchased a small Synology server and run an Active Directory domain on it. This often feels like overkill and more complexity for the guy who has to administer it (me), but it gives each student their own account, credentials, file system space, etc. It also gives us shared space to cache each year‚Äôs software packages, etc.

This approach has lessened chaos and conflicts once students climb the GitHub learning curve. We still manage to clobber each other once in a while.

Of course, this implies that you have the ability to administer the Windows laptops with impunity.

And yes, each laptop needs Windows Pro in this environment‚Ä¶ Sigh‚Ä¶

To be honest me and the programmers on my team just use each other‚Äôs GitHub accounts all the time. It‚Äôs very nice to read different perspectives here though.

For context, we have three programming laptops with each one having one team desktop account

posts.name: Nilesh Agarwalla
posts.cooked:
As promised, here‚Äôs the document describing the steps I took to setup the Samba AD-DC .

I‚Äôm hoping to put it into production this Monday!
